Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: Between a tree and a dry place - How competition and drought tolerance constrain tree geographic ranges
Award.AbstractNarration:
Identifying the main constraints on species ranges and how these constraints vary across the globe has proven remarkably difficult; the degree to which the environment alone or in combination with interactions with other organisms imposes the limit is the crux of the problem. This project will combine experiments, field studies, and species distribution models to test whether plant species along a gradient from dry to wetter environments are squeezed between death from drought on one side of their range and fierce competition with species adapted to wetter conditions on the other. The results can help explain when, where, and how tree range boundaries are constrained, thereby advancing the state of the science. Such information may help guide land managers who seek to prepare for a rapidly changing climatic future by suggesting which conservation and forecasting tools are relevant in what situations, and thus enhances national welfare. It will also improve science education through activities for high school students.

It has long been hypothesized that plants are constrained by a fundamental trade-off between competitive ability and environmental stress tolerance, because adaptations to tolerate stress are energetically costly and limit maximum growth rates. Using seedling experiments, dendrochronological techniques, and species distribution modeling, this project explores whether tree species inhabiting aridity gradients in the U.S. and Australia show a trade-off between fast growth (a proxy for competitive ability) and drought tolerance. It then tests whether this trade-off mirrors growth constraints on adult trees in the field, and whether the observed trade-off and/or systematic growth constraints explain species turnover across aridity gradients. For broader impacts a module based on this research will be developed and piloted in cooperation with high school teachers, and results will be communicated to the public through a university teaching greenhouse.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Unprecedented rates of human caused climate change are expected during the next century. Species range shifts, or species changing where they occur on the landscape, are one of the dominant ecological responses to a changing climate that we have observed in recent history (over the past 100 years) or reconstructed from studies of the distant past (during past glacial cycles). Thus, many, if not most species are expected to shift their geographic ranges over the next human generation, leading to many ecological challenges (as ecosystems reshuffle on the landscape), economic challenges (as valuable species move out of an area or pests move into an area), and difficulties for land managers (who are managing lands that may change drastically over the next century). Unfortunately, predicting species range shifts remains extremely challenging because we only poorly understand what determines where species occur to begin with. This project explored how competition and climate stress (e.g. drought) jointly determine where tree species occur in the Western USA and Australia. We tested whether trees must trade-off in their ability to compete for resources and to resist drought stress. If trees have to choose between competing and resisting drought, then most species occur where they do because they’re caught between more competitive trees on one side of their range and too much climate stress on the other side of their range.

 

This project revealed that, at very large scales (e.g. across the Western USA) climate and competition do trade-off to determine where species occur. However, at local scales (e.g. where one species occurs on one mountain), this trade-off is often much less apparent. We found that this compete-vs-tolerate drought trade-off is complicated by the particular strategies that plants use to cope with drought. Some trees may grow very quickly and prove competitive in short wet periods but then avoid drought and grow slowly during dry periods. Others may grow slowly all the time, but tolerate extreme droughts. Some trees even change their strategy over the course of their lifetime. This award facilitated research into the fundamental physiology of drought resistance, pushing forward our understanding of how trees cope with drought. In summary, the award led to ground-breaking research published in peer-reviewed scientific journals; resulted in multiple venues of outreach and science communication of project findings including podcasts, news articles, and education material; and trained numerous students and researchers in cutting-edge measurements in ecology and plant physiology. The award increased our understanding of the controls on species ranges and laid the groundwork for predicting where and when tree species may shift their ranges in the future.
